<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 117, 379, 142]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 332, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/12  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
February/March 2022  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 247, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 437, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 228, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 897, 522]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.- For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D. Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.- Write in soft pencil.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.- Do not use correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 549, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 570, 612]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- Each correct answer will score one mark.- Any rough working should be done on this question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[269, 847, 728, 864]]<|/det|>
This document has 20 pages. Any blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 564, 89]]<|/det|>

Both containers are the same size and both are sealed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 725, 668]]<|/det|> The water in container P cools more quickly than the water in container Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 681, 348, 698]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 709, 133, 727]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 709, 405, 726]]<|/det|> P contains more water than Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 736, 133, 754]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 736, 410, 753]]<|/det|> P has a shinier surface than Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 763, 133, 781]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 763, 447, 780]]<|/det|> P is painted a darker colour than Q. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 789, 133, 807]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 789, 623, 806]]<|/det|> P is surrounded by a vacuum and Q is surrounded by air.

Refraction is observed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 457, 406, 476]]<|/det|> What causes the ripples to refract? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 485, 134, 504]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 485, 591, 504]]<|/det|> The cold water in the tank is replaced by warm water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 513, 131, 532]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 513, 715, 532]]<|/det|> The ripples change speed as they move from deep to shallow water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 131, 559]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 540, 435, 558]]<|/det|> The ripples hit the wall of the tank. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 567, 131, 585]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 567, 477, 585]]<|/det|> The ripples pass through a narrow gap. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 609, 106, 628]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 680, 628]]<|/det|> The diagram shows a plane mirror and a ray of light reflected from it. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 640, 437, 657]]<|/det|> Which angle is the angle of incidence? <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 666, 625, 780]]<|/det|>

<label>26</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 584, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates sound waves from a loudspeaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
The frequency of the sound wave is \(25 000 \text{Hz}\). The student has normal hearing but she cannot hear the sound.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 147, 710, 164]]<|/det|>
What should she do if she wants to hear a sound from the loudspeaker?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 175, 138, 193]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 175, 349, 193]]<|/det|>
decrease the amplitude

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 202, 138, 220]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 202, 349, 220]]<|/det|>
decrease the frequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 228, 136, 247]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 228, 344, 245]]<|/det|>
increase the amplitude

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 254, 136, 272]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 254, 344, 272]]<|/det|>
increase the frequency

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 342, 628, 361]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 475, 106, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>28</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 920, 509]]<|/det|>
When a plastic comb is placed next to a small piece of aluminium foil hanging from a nylon thread, the foil is repelled by the comb.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 521, 220, 539]]<|/det|>
Why is this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 550, 133, 567]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 549, 541, 567]]<|/det|>
The comb is charged and the foil is uncharged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 577, 133, 594]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 575, 541, 594]]<|/det|>
The comb is uncharged and the foil is charged.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 603, 131, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 603, 589, 621]]<|/det|>
The comb and the foil have charges of opposite sign.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 630, 133, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 630, 596, 648]]<|/det|>
The comb and the foil have charges of the same sign.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 673, 106, 691]]<|/det|>
<label>29</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 673, 551, 691]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 732, 640, 749]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 761, 133, 778]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 761, 546, 778]]<|/det|>
a wire of the same length with a larger diameter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 787, 133, 805]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 787, 559, 804]]<|/det|>
a wire of the same length with a smaller diameter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 814, 133, 833]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 814, 544, 831]]<|/det|>
a wire of greater length with the same diameter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 841, 133, 858]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 841, 542, 858]]<|/det|>
a wire of greater length with a smaller diameter

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 359, 833, 378]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[371, 388, 621, 551]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 685, 581]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 591, 134, 609]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 591, 413, 610]]<|/det|>
P has a greater reading than Q.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 617, 134, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 617, 413, 636]]<|/det|>
P has a greater reading than R.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 644, 134, 662]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 413, 662]]<|/det|>
P has a greater reading than S.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 134, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 413, 688]]<|/det|>
P has a greater reading than T.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 714, 107, 733]]<|/det|>
<label>32</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 714, 920, 747]]<|/det|>
An electrician sets up a potential divider circuit in a fridge so that when the fridge door is open and light from the room enters the fridge, a warning light turns on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 759, 920, 793]]<|/det|>
Which component does the electrician need for the potential divider in addition to a variable resistor?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 803, 134, 821]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 803, 349, 821]]<|/det|>
light-dependent resistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 829, 141, 848]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 829, 196, 848]]<|/det|>
relay

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 857, 138, 875]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 857, 238, 874]]<|/det|>
thermistor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 883, 141, 900]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 883, 205, 900]]<|/det|>
motor

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 107, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>33</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 576, 91]]<|/det|>
A simple wiring diagram for an electric cooker is shown.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[287, 97, 707, 322]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 333, 688, 352]]<|/det|>
Why is there a wire connecting the metal case of the cooker to earth?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 362, 134, 380]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 362, 475, 381]]<|/det|>
It improves the efficiency of the cooker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 388, 133, 406]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 388, 777, 406]]<|/det|>
It prevents the metal case from becoming too hot when the cooker is left on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 131, 433]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 414, 784, 433]]<|/det|>
It reduces the risk of an electric shock if the live wire touches the metal case.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 441, 133, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 441, 539, 460]]<|/det|>
The electric cooker will not switch on without it.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 485, 106, 504]]<|/det|>
<label>34</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 485, 579, 504]]<|/det|>
Three statements about a.c. and d.c. currents are given.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[186, 515, 203, 534]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 515, 920, 549]]<|/det|>
A d.c. current is in one direction only whilst an a.c. current repeatedly changes direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 556, 205, 574]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 556, 920, 590]]<|/det|>
d.c. is the abbreviation for direct current and a.c. is the abbreviation for amplitude current.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[185, 598, 205, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[222, 598, 920, 631]]<|/det|>
An a.c. current is in one direction only whilst a d.c. current repeatedly changes direction.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 642, 371, 660]]<|/det|>
Which statements are correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 670, 134, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 670, 218, 688]]<|/det|>
1 and 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 670, 301, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 670, 373, 688]]<|/det|>
1 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[447, 670, 468, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 670, 504, 688]]<|/det|>
2 and 3

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 670, 636, 688]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[648, 670, 707, 688]]<|/det|>
3 only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 106, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>35</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 554, 91]]<|/det|>
Two magnets are placed near a current-carrying coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 101, 831, 121]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows this experimental arrangement and the current direction in the coil.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 128, 764, 228]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 238, 348, 256]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 266, 136, 285]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 266, 463, 285]]<|/det|>
Both X and Y are attracted to the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 293, 134, 312]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 293, 460, 312]]<|/det|>
Both X and Y are repelled by the coil.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 320, 134, 339]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 320, 505, 339]]<|/det|>
X is attracted to the coil and Y is repelled.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 345, 134, 364]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 345, 500, 364]]<|/det|>
X is repelled by the coil and Y is attracted.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 915, 920, 939]]<|/det|>
Cambridge Assessment International Education is part of Cambridge Assessment. Cambridge Assessment is the brand name of the University of Cambridge Local Examinations Syndicate (UCLES), which is a department of the University of Cambridge.
